PRICE, FIVE CENTS

IMPORTANT CHANGE PROPOSED
Athletic Board Decides to Ask Student
Body's Approval of Plan to Raise
Locker Fee to Ten Dollars.

At its last meeting, the Athletic
Board decided that it would submit
to the students the proposition of
raising the locker fee to ten dollars
at the annual meeting of the Athletic Association which is to be held
in _May. For this ten dollars the
student will receive not only his
locker, but also towels and a season
ticket to Homewood. The Board
will submit the proposition with the
recommendation that it be adopted.
The present fee is five dollars.
There are several reasons for this
change. In the first place the present fee is very low when compared
with those of other colleges of the
standing of Johns Hopkins, where
it is generally fifteen dollars. Secondly, it will enable every student
to be present at all games which are
played at Homewood, and thereby
do much to increase college spirit.
Thirdly, it will make much simpler
the collection of money as the locker
fee, towel service, and season tickets
are all paid for separately at present.
Before the change can go into effect, however, it must be approved
by the Board of Trustees. The
Athletic Board feels sure that this
approval will be given, provided the
students themselves are in favor of
such a step.
This action by the athletic authorities is sure to be favorably received, as it has been urged strongly
by many members of the University
for several years. It is a progressive move in the right direction,
and although some will probably
oppose it, it will most likely be in
operation next fall.
Rock Hill Game Off.

The opening game of the University's baseball season—that with
Rock Hill College—was called off
Saturday because of cold weather
and the condition of the Rock Hill
diamond, which was a patchwork
of snow and marsh. It has not yet
been decided whether the game will
be played later on in the season,
but inasmuch as it is a factor in
the race for the State championship,
there is a strong probability of
another date being named.
The University will play Princeton Saturday at Princeton, and the
lacrosse team will open the season
at Homewood with a picked alumni
team for its opponent.
Hopkins and Rock Hill were not
the only teams disappointed Saturday, for the Navy-Maryland "Aggies" and Georgetown-Mount St.
Joseph's games were also cancelled.

squads forsook their old haunts last
week, and tasted a little of real outdoor practice. The baseball men
gave the signal that the nineteenfourteen season is really here, by
holding their practice last Monday
on the old Country School grounds,
Charles street, near Homewood, our
own field being still in too soft a
condition to receive them. The
next day the lacrosse men followed
their example, and much energy
and good spirit was shown by all,
as they realized the long, steady
fight for the championship and for
places on the champion team was
making its real beginning for
another season. The cooler weather at the end of the week perhaps
dampened their enthusiastic feelings, but it served to enforce the
realization that the beginning was
being made sufficiently early. The
baseball men have actually opened
their season by their practice game
with Rock Hill on Saturday, and
the lacrosse men are looking forward to playing their first game
next week with the alumni. Guesses
• as to the line-up are being made
by all interested.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 23, 1914.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in announcing that it has joined
the Association of Eastern College
Newspapers, which was formed a
Year ago for the purpose of bringing together, annually, members of
the boards of the various college
papers in this part of the country.
The Association counts among its
members such well known college
papers as the Cornell Sun, the best
college daily in the country; the
Daily Princetonian, the Pennsylvanian, the Harvard Crimson, and
the Yale News. The Association
hopes in the very near future to
be able to establish a central college
news bureau to furnish exchanges
to the constituent members.
The New Freshman Rule.

The suggestion that freshman attendance at the organization meetings of the college's various activities be made compulsory, which
was embodied in a letter from "A
Much Interested Alumnus," printed
last week, has met with the approval of a majority of the students
and has received the unanimous endorsement of the members of the
Student Council.
Briefly, the suggestion is this:
For the purpose of getting every
one of the members of the incoming class interested in the college's
activities, and making them feel that
they are wanted as candidates for
the various athletic teams and as
members of the Musical Clubs and
the Literary Society—providing, of
course, that they have the neces-.
sary talents—it is proposed that a
rule be inserted in the "Code of
Freshman Regulations" providing
compulsory freshman attendance at
the organization meetings.

There is significance in the rapidity
with which articles on the colleges arc
appearing in the public press; evidently
colleges are growing in some sort of
reputation and are receiving notice accordingly. The latest discussion is in
the current Outlook and is a substantiated opinion that colleges are giving
valuable business training. This is
scarcely in accord with Mr. Bok, who
stated in the same magazine last summer
that good business men avoid col:ege
graduates until they have had time to
have foolish ideals and ideas knocked
from their heads.. And this article does
not blame the college for the fools
that sometimes graduate from it. Mr.
Draper, the author of the recent article,
has taken the trouble to get actual facts
from a number of prominent industrial
executives. This is more than most
critics of the college have done, and the
result is that his conclusions differ from
most of theirs. He says that "the consensus of opinion and the weight of evidence show that, as a rule, the college
man goes the non-college man one
better."
That is the conclusion. What are the
reasons? In the first place, Mr. Draper
believes that no man can lead a business
without clear and "workable" ideas; and
that "the harnessing of the imagination"
can best be learned in college, for in
college "he who knows, but cannot express what he knows, is no better off
than as if he did not know at all." In
the second place, "college life is a life
among ideals," and business is fast learning that it is not "alone a game of outwitting and profiting," but of "benefiting
the community" and individual, "morally,
as well as materially."
Yet, Mr. Draper is not all praise. He
says that we cannot get away from the
fact that college men are apt to be extravagant, careless and lacking in application. Fortunately, these generally
prove to be superficial traits, soon overcome, but they indicate the course which
college men should pursue in their reforms. We know from experience that
carelessness, at least, is a college failing.

Arden" to Strauss's musical setting,
which was given last Friday evening in McCoy Hall by Mr. Herbert
Bard, assisted by Mr. Thomas
Moss, pianist, of the Tome School
for Boys, afforded a most delightful evening's entertainment for the
large number of people present.
Mr. Bard's reading of the poem
was most pleasing; he was easily
heard and understood throughout
the hall, and his interpretation of
the characters was intensely fascinating in its reality of impression

Dr. Spieker's Operation.

Dr. Edward H. Spieker, associate
professor of Greek in the collegiate
faculty, who has been under the
care of Dr. L. F. Barker at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital for a period of seven weeks, was operated
on last Friday by Dr. J. M. T.
Finney, for ulcer of the stomach.
The operation was successful; the
Ulcer was completely removed by
Dr. Finney, and was discovered not
to have been at all malignant. Dr.
Spieker is now slowly recuperating
at his room in the Marburg Building, and although he is suffering
much pain as a result of the disturbed condition of his stomach,
his general condition has been pronounced good by Dr. Finney.

"In regard to the inclusion of the
purchase of a season ticket in the
required gymnasium fee, the Student Council's power would only
extend to recommendation to those
above; but to such a scheme I
should be opposed as unjustified."
Walter D. Sutton, president of
the Athletic Association and the
second senior on the Council said:
"In striving to obtain a good attendance at the mass-meetings last
fall great difficulty was experienced.
The suggested rule will do much
to obviate this.,
"If the compulsory attendance
developes the desire to take an interest in college activities, these requirements will be good, not only
for the freshman, but for the whole
University."
William A. Baker, the secretary
of the Council, said:
"The idea of compelling all freshmen to attend the various organization meetings seems to me to be
a sound method for procuring the
much desired increase in 'college
spirit.'
"If we hope to iucceed in arousing the student body to participate
more energetically in student activities, it is only proper tlit we begin with the freshmen. At the same
time this movement will stimulate
and increase the enthusiasm among
the upperclass men."
Emmett R. Spencer, the other
junior representative, writes:
"The suggestion of THE NEwsLETTER has some good and some
bad points. It is highly desirable
to have all students attend each organization meeting, and by compelling, by the means suggested, the
freshman to attend such meetings,
may inspire in him a permanent interest in student and University activities. If that end is accomplished,
then the suggestion is good.
"As for the suggestion relative
to fussing, I am not in favor of it.
I believe in a manly, University
regulation of freshmen, and not in
a boyish high school form of regulation." Hiram W. Woodward,
sophomore delegate, said:
"The idea of compelling all freshmen to attend the various organization meetings is a good one, for it
is only at these meetings that they
may fully learn of the non-scholastic
activities and of their place in the
life of the college.
"The only' difficulty is the enforcement of the rule, but with
some such plan as the publication
of the names of the absentees, fear
of public opinion would force almost every freshman to be present."
Paul Sutton holds the opinion:
"As the freshman representative
on the Student Council, I heartily
agree with the plans which have
been suggested, and hope that the
' present freshman class will put
them into practice at once. We can
attend the lacrosse and baseball
games -and track meets this spring.

Dr. Caswell Grave, oyster expert,
and associate professor of zoology
in this University, has come prominently into the public eye during
the last two weeks, by reason of his
activity in the present oyster fight
in the Legislature.
Last Tuesday a two-column letter accompanied by Dr. Grave's
picture was the most striking bit
of news on the front page of the
evening Sun. In this letter the
Hopkins biologist replied strongly
and pointedly to recent personal
attacks made on him and his motives by Senator Milbourne, and
demanded an apology and a retraction of the statements.
On the whole, Dr. Grave has had
the better of his controversy with
Milbourne, and the strength of his
public letter was the occasion of
much favOrable comment throughout the city. Dr. Grave will continue to fight for oyster culture until
the end of the Legislature's session,
lending the benefit of his long years
of experience as a shell-fish commissioner to the supporters of the
present laws.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH

23, 1914.

PEACE CONTEST NEXT FRIDAY
Large Number of Entries Assures Interesting Meeting—Hopkins Will Be
Represented-- Committees.

The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Peace Contest, held under
the joint auspices of the Maryland
Peace Society and the Hopkins
Grotius Society, will take place in
McCoy Hall on next Friday evening at eight o'clock.
The colleges which will be represented are: Johns Hopkins University, St. John's College, Loyola
College and probably Georgetown
University and the Maryland Agricultural College.
The Hopkins speaker will be
Moses Baroway, '15, whose oration
will be on the subject "Disillusionment."
The cause of St. John's will be
defended by Orville M. Moore,
whose speech is entitled "Some
Beneficial Aspects of International
Peace."
Jerome H. Joyce will represent
Loyola and he will try to capture
the laurels for his school with a presentation of the subject of "A
Simple Method for Forwarding
Universal Peace."
Washington College will not be
represented in the contest this year.
The student committees to take
charge of the affair in McCoy Hall
are composed of the following:
Committee on General Arrangements — H. W. Richmond, '14,
chairman; A. K. Barton, '14; C. I.
Uhler, 'I5-.
Committee on Invitations—Aaron
Schaffer, '14, chairman; F. A.
Hahn, '14; G. M. Hall, 'i5; S. L.
Leitheiser, 'i6; H. L. Dryden, '17.
Committee on Music — Roland
Gminder, 14, chairman; E. R.Spencer, "5; E. M. Spieker, '16.
Reception Committee — L. B.
Chenoweth, '14, chairman; R. Leibensperger, '14; S. J. Keiser, '14;
C. J. Weber,'14; R. W. Smith,'i5;
L. C. Cohn, '15; W. A. Baker, Jr.,
'15; E. P. Hayes, 'i6; C. W. McDowell, 'i6; L. H. Baker,'17.
Those who are unable to serve
on any of these committees will
please notify the Committee on
General Arrangements at once.
The judges of the contest, chosen
by the Maryland Peace Society,
are: Rabbi Charles A. Rubinstein,
Dr:0. Edward Janney, Mr. W. H.
Morriss, ex-Judge Alfred S. Niles
and Father Louis O'Donovan.
The winner of the contest will
receive a prize of seventy-five dollars, as well as the right to compete in the group contest to be held
in April. If he waives this right,
however, it will devolve upon the
man- who finishes second best on
Friday night.

The Rev. Dr. Joel Swartz, theologian, educator and writer, died last
Monday morning at the home of his
son, Prof. Charles K. Swartz, at
Windsor Park.

One thousand students at Wisconsin either failed or were conditioned after the mid-winter examinations. This indicates that one

Next Cotillon on May 2 or 9.

Because of the fact that on May
9, the date originally decided upon
for the next cotillon, the baseball
team will be away on a trip, there
has been some discussion by the
Board in favor of a change in date
to May 2.
This matter will probably be decided at the next meeting of the
Board, which will take place within
a few days.
Another thing which will in all
probability be done- at this meeting
is the fixing of 8.30 P. M. as the
time for beginning the cotillon, instead of 9 P. M., which has hitherto
been the usual hour.

BALTIMORE

"Hullabaloo" Progress.

The work of engraving on the
1914 Hullabaloo is now well under
way, but is being slightly hampered
by the fact that all of the photographs which are to go into the
book have not yet been submitted to
the board of editors. Members of
the senior class who still have photographs to send in are requested
by the business manager to attend
to this matter at once, so that the
engraving work may be put forward with all possible dispatch.
Photographs printed on glossy velox, to be reproduced in the Hullabaloo, are especially desired as soon
as possible.
The date on which the book will
go to press has been set as April 1.
This has made it necessary for the
board to announce that all copy
positively must be in this week.
The business manager will be
glad to pay 25 per cent, on any advertisements which students obtain
for the Hullabaloo. This offer is
open to all students; and, since the
advertisements are especially needed now, any Hopkins man who can
secure an ad. for the Hullabaloo is
earnestly urged to make use of his
ability now.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

IMPORTANT CHANGE PROPOSED
Athletic Board Decides to Ask Student
Body's Approval of Plan to Raise
Locker Fee to Ten Dollars.

At its last meeting, the Athletic
Board decided that it would submit
to the students the proposition of
raising the locker fee to ten dollars
at the annual meeting of the Athletic Association which is to be held
in _May. For this ten dollars the
student will receive not only his
locker, but also towels and a season
ticket to Homewood. The Board
will submit the proposition with the
recommendation that it be adopted.
The present fee is five dollars.
There are several reasons for this
change. In the first place the present fee is very low when compared
with those of other colleges of the
standing of Johns Hopkins, where
it is generally fifteen dollars. Secondly, it will enable every student
to be present at all games which are
played at Homewood, and thereby
do much to increase college spirit.
Thirdly, it will make much simpler
the collection of money as the locker
fee, towel service, and season tickets
are all paid for separately at present.
Before the change can go into effect, however, it must be approved
by the Board of Trustees. The
Athletic Board feels sure that this
approval will be given, provided the
students themselves are in favor of
such a step.
This action by the athletic authorities is sure to be favorably received, as it has been urged strongly
by many members of the University
for several years. It is a progressive move in the right direction,
and although some will probably
oppose it, it will most likely be in
operation next fall.
Rock Hill Game Off.

The opening game of the University's baseball season—that with
Rock Hill College—was called off
Saturday because of cold weather
and the condition of the Rock Hill
diamond, which was a patchwork
of snow and marsh. It has not yet
been decided whether the game will
be played later on in the season,
but inasmuch as it is a factor in
the race for the State championship,
there is a strong probability of
another date being named.
The University will play Princeton Saturday at Princeton, and the
lacrosse team will open the season
at Homewood with a picked alumni
team for its opponent.
Hopkins and Rock Hill were not
the only teams disappointed Saturday, for the Navy-Maryland "Aggies" and Georgetown-Mount St.
Joseph's games were also cancelled.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. 23, 1914.

THE NEWS-LETTER takes pleasure
in announcing that it has joined
the Association of Eastern College
Newspapers, which was formed a
Year ago for the purpose of bringing together, annually, members of
the boards of the various college
papers in this part of the country.
The Association counts among its
members such well known college
papers as the Cornell Sun, the best
college daily in the country; the
Daily Princetonian, the Pennsylvanian, the Harvard Crimson, and
the Yale News. The Association
hopes in the very near future to
be able to establish a central college
news bureau to furnish exchanges
to the constituent members.
The New Freshman Rule.

The suggestion that freshman attendance at the organization meetings of the college's various activities be made compulsory, which
was embodied in a letter from "A
Much Interested Alumnus," printed
last week, has met with the approval of a majority of the students
and has received the unanimous endorsement of the members of the
Student Council.
Briefly, the suggestion is this:
For the purpose of getting every
one of the members of the incoming class interested in the college's
activities, and making them feel that
they are wanted as candidates for
the various athletic teams and as
members of the Musical Clubs and
the Literary Society—providing, of
course, that they have the neces-.
sary talents—it is proposed that a
rule be inserted in the "Code of
Freshman Regulations" providing
compulsory freshman attendance at
the organization meetings.

There is significance in the rapidity
with which articles on the colleges arc
appearing in the public press; evidently
colleges are growing in some sort of
reputation and are receiving notice accordingly. The latest discussion is in
the current Outlook and is a substantiated opinion that colleges are giving
valuable business training. This is
scarcely in accord with Mr. Bok, who
stated in the same magazine last summer
that good business men avoid col:ege
graduates until they have had time to
have foolish ideals and ideas knocked
from their heads.. And this article does
not blame the college for the fools
that sometimes graduate from it. Mr.
Draper, the author of the recent article,
has taken the trouble to get actual facts
from a number of prominent industrial
executives. This is more than most
critics of the college have done, and the
result is that his conclusions differ from
most of theirs. He says that "the consensus of opinion and the weight of evidence show that, as a rule, the college
man goes the non-college man one
better."
That is the conclusion. What are the
reasons? In the first place, Mr. Draper
believes that no man can lead a business
without clear and "workable" ideas; and
that "the harnessing of the imagination"
can best be learned in college, for in
college "he who knows, but cannot express what he knows, is no better off
than as if he did not know at all." In
the second place, "college life is a life
among ideals," and business is fast learning that it is not "alone a game of outwitting and profiting," but of "benefiting
the community" and individual, "morally,
as well as materially."
Yet, Mr. Draper is not all praise. He
says that we cannot get away from the
fact that college men are apt to be extravagant, careless and lacking in application. Fortunately, these generally
prove to be superficial traits, soon overcome, but they indicate the course which
college men should pursue in their reforms. We know from experience that
carelessness, at least, is a college failing.
Reading of "Enoch Arden."

The reading of Tennyson's "Enoch
Arden" to Strauss's musical setting,
which was given last Friday evening in McCoy Hall by Mr. Herbert
Bard, assisted by Mr. Thomas
Moss, pianist, of the Tome School
for Boys, afforded a most delightful evening's entertainment for the
large number of people present.
Mr. Bard's reading of the poem
was most pleasing; he was easily
heard and understood throughout
the hall, and his interpretation of
the characters was intensely fascinating in its reality of impression

Dr. Spieker's Operation.

Dr. Edward H. Spieker, associate
professor of Greek in the collegiate
faculty, who has been under the
care of Dr. L. F. Barker at the
Johns Hopkins Hospital for a period of seven weeks, was operated
on last Friday by Dr. J. M. T.
Finney, for ulcer of the stomach.
The operation was successful; the
Ulcer was completely removed by
Dr. Finney, and was discovered not
to have been at all malignant. Dr.
Spieker is now slowly recuperating
at his room in the Marburg Building, and although he is suffering
much pain as a result of the disturbed condition of his stomach,
his general condition has been pronounced good by Dr. Finney.

"In regard to the inclusion of the
purchase of a season ticket in the
required gymnasium fee, the Student Council's power would only
extend to recommendation to those
above; but to such a scheme I
should be opposed as unjustified."
Walter D. Sutton, president of
the Athletic Association and the
second senior on the Council said:
"In striving to obtain a good attendance at the mass-meetings last
fall great difficulty was experienced.
The suggested rule will do much
to obviate this.,
"If the compulsory attendance
developes the desire to take an interest in college activities, these requirements will be good, not only
for the freshman, but for the whole
University."
William A. Baker, the secretary
of the Council, said:
"The idea of compelling all freshmen to attend the various organization meetings seems to me to be
a sound method for procuring the
much desired increase in 'college
spirit.'
"If we hope to iucceed in arousing the student body to participate
more energetically in student activities, it is only proper tlit we begin with the freshmen. At the same
time this movement will stimulate
and increase the enthusiasm among
the upperclass men."
Emmett R. Spencer, the other
junior representative, writes:
"The suggestion of THE NEwsLETTER has some good and some
bad points. It is highly desirable
to have all students attend each organization meeting, and by compelling, by the means suggested, the
freshman to attend such meetings,
may inspire in him a permanent interest in student and University activities. If that end is accomplished,
then the suggestion is good.
"As for the suggestion relative
to fussing, I am not in favor of it.
I believe in a manly, University
regulation of freshmen, and not in
a boyish high school form of regulation." Hiram W. Woodward,
sophomore delegate, said:
"The idea of compelling all freshmen to attend the various organization meetings is a good one, for it
is only at these meetings that they
may fully learn of the non-scholastic
activities and of their place in the
life of the college.
"The only' difficulty is the enforcement of the rule, but with
some such plan as the publication
of the names of the absentees, fear
of public opinion would force almost every freshman to be present."
Paul Sutton holds the opinion:
"As the freshman representative
on the Student Council, I heartily
agree with the plans which have
been suggested, and hope that the
' present freshman class will put
them into practice at once. We can
attend the lacrosse and baseball
games -and track meets this spring.

Dr. Caswell Grave, oyster expert,
and associate professor of zoology
in this University, has come prominently into the public eye during
the last two weeks, by reason of his
activity in the present oyster fight
in the Legislature.
Last Tuesday a two-column letter accompanied by Dr. Grave's
picture was the most striking bit
of news on the front page of the
evening Sun. In this letter the
Hopkins biologist replied strongly
and pointedly to recent personal
attacks made on him and his motives by Senator Milbourne, and
demanded an apology and a retraction of the statements.
On the whole, Dr. Grave has had
the better of his controversy with
Milbourne, and the strength of his
public letter was the occasion of
much favOrable comment throughout the city. Dr. Grave will continue to fight for oyster culture until
the end of the Legislature's session,
lending the benefit of his long years
of experience as a shell-fish commissioner to the supporters of the
present laws.

PEACE CONTEST NEXT FRIDAY
Large Number of Entries Assures Interesting Meeting—Hopkins Will Be
Represented-- Committees.

The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Peace Contest, held under
the joint auspices of the Maryland
Peace Society and the Hopkins
Grotius Society, will take place in
McCoy Hall on next Friday evening at eight o'clock.
The colleges which will be represented are: Johns Hopkins University, St. John's College, Loyola
College and probably Georgetown
University and the Maryland Agricultural College.
The Hopkins speaker will be
Moses Baroway, '15, whose oration
will be on the subject "Disillusionment."
The cause of St. John's will be
defended by Orville M. Moore,
whose speech is entitled "Some
Beneficial Aspects of International
Peace."
Jerome H. Joyce will represent
Loyola and he will try to capture
the laurels for his school with a presentation of the subject of "A
Simple Method for Forwarding
Universal Peace."
Washington College will not be
represented in the contest this year.
The student committees to take
charge of the affair in McCoy Hall
are composed of the following:
Committee on General Arrangements — H. W. Richmond, '14,
chairman; A. K. Barton, '14; C. I.
Uhler, 'I5-.
Committee on Invitations—Aaron
Schaffer, '14, chairman; F. A.
Hahn, '14; G. M. Hall, 'i5; S. L.
Leitheiser, 'i6; H. L. Dryden, '17.
Committee on Music — Roland
Gminder, 14, chairman; E. R.Spencer, "5; E. M. Spieker, '16.
Reception Committee — L. B.
Chenoweth, '14, chairman; R. Leibensperger, '14; S. J. Keiser, '14;
C. J. Weber,'14; R. W. Smith,'i5;
L. C. Cohn, '15; W. A. Baker, Jr.,
'15; E. P. Hayes, 'i6; C. W. McDowell, 'i6; L. H. Baker,'17.
Those who are unable to serve
on any of these committees will
please notify the Committee on
General Arrangements at once.
The judges of the contest, chosen
by the Maryland Peace Society,
are: Rabbi Charles A. Rubinstein,
Dr:0. Edward Janney, Mr. W. H.
Morriss, ex-Judge Alfred S. Niles
and Father Louis O'Donovan.
The winner of the contest will
receive a prize of seventy-five dollars, as well as the right to compete in the group contest to be held
in April. If he waives this right,
however, it will devolve upon the
man- who finishes second best on
Friday night.

Next Cotillon on May 2 or 9.

BALTIMORE

"Hullabaloo" Progress.

The work of engraving on the
1914 Hullabaloo is now well under
way, but is being slightly hampered
by the fact that all of the photographs which are to go into the
book have not yet been submitted to
the board of editors. Members of
the senior class who still have photographs to send in are requested
by the business manager to attend
to this matter at once, so that the
engraving work may be put forward with all possible dispatch.
Photographs printed on glossy velox, to be reproduced in the Hullabaloo, are especially desired as soon
as possible.
The date on which the book will
go to press has been set as April 1.
This has made it necessary for the
board to announce that all copy
positively must be in this week.
The business manager will be
glad to pay 25 per cent, on any advertisements which students obtain
for the Hullabaloo. This offer is
open to all students; and, since the
advertisements are especially needed now, any Hopkins man who can
secure an ad. for the Hullabaloo is
earnestly urged to make use of his
ability now.
